content: every good tavern needs a place to order a drink so today I'm building a bar hey
guys welcome back to another episode of black magic crafts today I am going to
continue on my tavern set this set is something that I'm building to give away
to one of my patreon supporters and it's gonna include the tables I built last
episode a bar that I'm building today and some bookcases that I'm gonna build
next episode if you want to find out how you can win that you gotta head over to
my patreon page and support the channel they're building a little Styrofoam bar
is not the most complicated or exciting of projects however I made this project
more fun and challenging to myself by setting the guideline that it needed to
be modular and configurable in different sizes and layouts and I'm pretty happy
with the results because this is a speed build and my time is limited I'm going
to build this using the tools at my disposal like the procs on Hotwire table
of course you don't actually need to use the same tools and material that I use
in this build if you don't have them at your disposal
just take the inspiration and build this with whatever you have dollar-store foam
core if you have this available is a great stand in for the XPS foam and it's
really easy to work with just with an exacto or utility knife also if you do
have XPS foam but no hot wire table you can absolutely pull off this build just
with a sharp utility knife so let's get to it let's build a damn bar because I
need it I need a drink even in a simple build like this it's sometimes important
to do some pre-planning and test pieces with this build it was really important
to me that the set be modular and be able to be set up in a lot of different
configurations and sizes so I cut a few test pieces on a card stock that I could
play around with and figure out exactly what I wanted to build in the end I
decided that 3 middle sections that were 2 inches long and two ends sections that
were 3 inches long and included a round corner would give me the most
versatility so once I knew what I wanted to build I set out breaking down some
material to give me all the pieces that I could use to assemble this bar and
it's important to notice here that I didn't fully measure and plan out
thicknesses of materials I just sort of eyeballed it and held the pieces
together until they looked about the right size that I wanted to make the
round corner pieces I used my shifting Lance comm circle cutting jig to cut a
foam circle with a one-inch radius I then took that circle and cut it down to
the same thickness as the other pieces that I had already made for the bar top
once I had all my raw pieces pre-made I said about cutting them up into
individual pieces I took the circles that I had made and
cut them down into quarters to act as the round corners on the bar I'm just
using the grid on my cutting mat and an x-acto knife I cut all of the tabletop
pieces to length as well as all the bottom strips this is a situation where
I could have done this on the hot wire table and had it done really quickly and
really uniformly but I didn't need to and I could do it just as effectively
with a knife and a ruler I did the woodgrain on these the same way I did on
the table build with a mechanical pencil I really liked the exaggerated woodgrain
on little pieces like this it really from a distance
reads like raw timber one thing to keep in mind when you're doing this kind of
wood grain is make sure that that grain carries around on all edges in a way
that actually makes sense like wood grain
once I had all the woodgrain complete I
said about gluing all the pieces together and I did this using Eileen's
tacky glue this stuff is essentially just a really thick PVA glue with less
water in it which means that it dries faster but also because it's thicker it
actually holds the pieces together a bit better before they dry and to apply this
I put on a pretty heavy coating just using an old paintbrush the pieces only
really needed to sit about 20 or 30 minutes before they were ready to really
handle again now one thing I'd like to highlight is a little mistake that came
up during the assembly some of the bottom pieces ended up a little bit
longer than the top pieces and you know what it's not really a big deal I just
cut them off flush after and then redrew in the end woodgrain and every bit of
train could use a cool little backstory detail and I really like the idea of
some brave adventurers sitting at this bar running their blades across it as
they shared stories so I decided to carve in some little extra details onto
the top some gashes and of course a little heart and with the build complete
it was time to put on the black magic craft base coat the Mod Podge and black
paint combo that seals and hardens the foam
the paint job here is pretty simple and pretty much the same as the table build
started with a medium brown that I mixed out of a espresso and a kind of golden
brown followed that up with a dry brushing of just this golden brown color
and topped it off with a light highlight dry brushing with a light tan the final
painting step was to apply the dark brown wash and I had saved this exact
same wash that I used on the table set so that I could carry it through to this
project once the wash dried I finished the whole
thing off with a nice coat of Minwax fast-drying polyurethane in a satin
finish this is how I complete all of my foam projects it seals them in it
enhances the color and it will make them last a lot longer I'm really happy with
the way this bar turned out I like the idea that it can be configured in a
bunch of different ways and I really like the little extra back story details
carved into the surface there you have it guys a very simple little project
that you can bang out in a weekend I would love to see your versions of this
project I would love it if you posted them on the tabletop crafters guild on
facebook if you're unfamiliar or not a member it is by far the biggest
community of tabletop crafters making stuff for role-playing games on Facebook
the link is in the description head on over join it's an awesome community post
your versions of my builds there I would love to see them also speaking of
Facebook if you'd like to join the black magic craft fellowship on Facebook a
great little tight community of fellow like-minded crafters building black
magic craft projects head on over to my patreon page there you can become a
member of the Fellowship and support this channel and these videos because I
need that support and I love it and thank you to all my patreon supporters
of course if you want to pick up any of the tools and supplies that I used in
this build or other builds head on over to black magic crafts I see a there you
can find my Amazon affiliate store where you can buy all of my favorite stuff and
help out the Chan in the process also a great place to do
your holiday shopping and buy some cool stuff for friends and family I hope that
you found this video in this series useful and inspiring if you did hit that
like button drop me a comment below and of course hit subscribe if you are not
already a subscriber until next week guys Cheers and happy crafting
